paragraphs.text:
%md

# Machine Learning Example -- Classification

<ralph.schlosser@gmail.com>

## Data Set

The data set is the SA heart data set from the excellent "Elements of Statistical Learning" book which is available for free here: <http://statweb.stanford.edu/~tibs/ElemStatLearn/>

## Purpose

In this example we're applying:

* Logistic Regression
* LASSO Logistic Regression
* Random Forests
* Support Vector Machines

to a classification problem.

result.msg:
Machine Learning Example – Classification

ralph.schlosser@gmail.com

Data Set

The data set is the SA heart data set from the excellent “Elements of Statistical Learning” book which is available for free here: http://statweb.stanford.edu/~tibs/ElemStatLearn/

Purpose

In this example we're applying:

  • Logistic Regression
  • LASSO Logistic Regression
  • Random Forests
  • Support Vector Machines

to a classification problem.

paragraphs.text:
%python # Some pre-requisites. import os import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import StringIO from pandas import Series, DataFrame import pandas as pd import numpy as np # The below is necessary to use matplotlib from Zeppelin. plt.rcdefaults() plt.switch_backend('agg') os.system("export DISPLAY=:0") # Display the plot result inline. def show(p): img = StringIO.StringIO() p.savefig(img, format='svg') img.seek(0) print "%html
" + img.buf + "
" # Read data from the web. SA = pd.read_csv('http://statweb.stanford.edu/~tibs/ElemStatLearn/datasets/SAheart.data') # # Data preparation # X_raw = SA.drop(['row.names', 'famhist', 'chd'], axis=1) X_raw_2 = (X_raw - X_raw.mean()) / X_raw.std() # Note: slightly unbalanced classes. y = SA.chd # Create scatter plot. pd.scatter_matrix(X_raw_2) # Some very correlated, one almost looks binary # Add some noise columns. np.random.seed(123) X = X_raw.join(DataFrame(np.random.randn(len(y), 100))) # Training / test size: 347 / 116 train_size = 347 # Set seed for reproducibility. np.random.seed(123) # # Split data in test / training sets. # train_select = np.random.permutation(range(len(y))) X_train = X.ix[train_select[:train_size], :].reset_index(drop=True) X_test = X.ix[train_select[train_size:], :].reset_index(drop=True) y_train = y[train_select[:train_size]].reset_index(drop=True) y_test = y[train_select[train_size:]].reset_index(drop=True) # # Logistic regression. # from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression logreg = LogisticRegression() logreg.fit(X_train, y_train) # Predict classes. logreg_test_pred = logreg.predict(X_test) # Mis-classification. logreg_cross = pd.crosstab(logreg_test_pred, y_test).astype('float') logreg_mis = (logreg_cross.ix[0, 1] + logreg_cross.ix[1, 0]) / np.sum(logreg_cross.values) # Predict probabilities. logreg_test_prob = logreg.predict_proba(X_test) # # LASSO logistic regression. # # C is the lasso penalty. lassologreg = LogisticRegression(penalty='l1', C = 0.1) lassologreg.fit(X_train, y_train) # Predict classes. lassologreg_test_pred = lassologreg.predict(X_test) # Mis-classification. lassologreg_cross = pd.crosstab(lassologreg_test_pred,y_test).astype('float') lasso_mis = (lassologreg_cross.ix[0, 1] + lassologreg_cross.ix[1, 0]) / np.sum(lassologreg_cross.values) # Predict probabilities. lassologreg_test_prob = lassologreg.predict_proba(X_test) # Bizarrely in two columns # # Random forest classification. # from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier rf_clf = RandomForestClassifier() rf_clf_fit = rf_clf.fit(X_train, y_train) rf_clf_test_pred = rf_clf_fit.predict(X_test) rf_clf_cross = pd.crosstab(rf_clf_test_pred, y_test).astype('float') rf_mis = (rf_clf_cross.ix[0, 1] + rf_clf_cross.ix[1, 0]) / np.sum(rf_clf_cross.values) # 0.365 # Predict probabilities. rf_test_prob = rf_clf_fit.predict_proba(X_test) # Bizarrely in two columns # # SVM classification # from sklearn import svm svm_clf = svm.SVC(probability=True) svm_clf_fit = svm_clf.fit(X_train, y_train) svm_clf_test_pred = svm_clf_fit.predict(X_test) svm_clf_cross = pd.crosstab(svm_clf_test_pred,y_test).astype('float') svm_mis = (svm_clf_cross.ix[0, 0] + svm_clf_cross.ix[0, 1]) / np.sum(svm_clf_cross.values) # Predict probabilities svm_test_prob = svm_clf_fit.predict_proba(X_test) # Bizarrely in two columns # Can create slightly stupid plots of the misclassification matrix plt.matshow(rf_clf_cross) plt.colorbar() # Create ROC curve and AUC for each of the above from sklearn.metrics import roc_curve, auc roc_lr = roc_curve(y_test, logreg_test_prob[:,1]) # Returns fpr, tpr, cutoffs lr_auc = auc(roc_lr[0], roc_lr[1]) roc_lassolr = roc_curve(y_test, lassologreg_test_prob[:,1]) lassolr_auc = auc(roc_lassolr[0],roc_lassolr[1]) roc_rf = roc_curve(y_test, rf_test_prob[:,1]) rf_auc = auc(roc_rf[0],roc_rf[1]) roc_svm = roc_curve(y_test, svm_test_prob[:,1]) svm_auc = auc(roc_svm[0],roc_svm[1]) # Now plot and label: plt.figure() plt.plot(roc_lr[0], roc_lr[1], label='Logistic regression (AUC = {0:0.2f})'''.format(lr_auc)) plt.plot(roc_lassolr[0], roc_lassolr[1], label='Lasso logistic regression (AUC = {0:0.2f})'''.format(lassolr_auc)) plt.plot(roc_rf[0], roc_rf[1], label='Random forest classification (AUC = {0:0.2f})'''.format(rf_auc)) plt.plot(roc_svm[0], roc_svm[1], label='Support vector machine classification (AUC = {0:0.2f})'''.format(svm_auc)) plt.legend(loc='lower right') plt.xlim([0.0, 1.0]) plt.ylim([0.0, 1.05]) plt.xlabel('False Positive Rate') plt.ylabel('True Positive Rate') plt.title('ROC curves for three different models applied to SA heart data') show(plt)

result.msg:
Logistic Regression: 0.365217391304
LASSO Logistic Regression: 0.339130434783
Random Forest: 0.4

paragraphs.text:
%python

print "Logistic Regression: " + str(logreg_mis)
print "LASSO Logistic Regression: " + str(lasso_mis)
print "Random Forest: " + str(rf_mis)
#print "SVM: " + str(svm_mis)
